awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing the Lambda Cold Dark Matter Paradigm with Dwarf Satellites of Low-mass Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
All large galaxies, like our own Milky Way, are surrounded by many smaller "satellite" companion galaxies. Scientists have recently discovered tiny satellite galaxies around the Large Magellanic Cloud, a small Milky Way companion galaxy. Current predictions are not able to reproduce the numbers and properties of these satellite galaxies. Small "dwarf" galaxies thus challenge our understanding of the physical processes that shape galaxies. To solve the puzzle, this project explores galaxies beyond the Milky Way and its Local Group of galaxies. The investigators will test predictions by searching for the tiniest satellites around small galaxies beyond our Local Group. These satellites are predicted to be faint and can only be found using the most advanced telescopes on Earth. The properties of the new objects will be compared to satellites in our Local Group and interpreted in the context of theoretical models. 

The three investigators, together with a postdoctoral researcher and students, will use state-of-the-art instrumentation on large optical telescopes to perform systematic, panoramic imaging surveys of 11 sub-Milky Way-mass target galaxies. The research team will interpret this census of faint satellites with the aid of dedicated analytical models. The final goal is to inform our understanding of the galaxy formation physics at the lowest mass scales. These observations can reveal how the stellar content of dwarf galaxies relates to their dark matter halos. The results will be interpreted as a function of galaxy environment, halo mass and morphology, thus providing quantitative constraints for star formation, feedback and re-ionization prescriptions in the framework of galaxy formation models.

The Investigators will use this research to increase the involvement of underrepresented minorities in astronomy by developing a support network for women in science at the University of Tampa. This will provide valuable guidance for their future careers and advise them on gender balance issues. At Ohio State University (OSU), astronomy-themed YouTube coding videos will be developed for high school students. Additionally, a peer-mentoring program led by OSU students will be supported by this program through participation in a dedicated Leadership Retreat.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our Milky Way galaxy is surrounded by dozens of tiny galaxies, swirling around us.  The number of these tiny galaxies tell us something about what our universe is made of and how it grew.  The colors of these galaxies, and the ages of the stars in them, tell us how these smallest of galaxies grow, and how their growth is affected by their closeness to the Milky Way.

 

The goal of this study is to count tiny galaxies near galaxies smaller than the Milky Way (in particular, around galaxies similar to the Magellanic Clouds, which are visible in the southern sky), and determine if they behave the same way as tiny galaxies do around the Milky Way.  We used telescopes in Chile, Hawaii, and space to find and measure these tiny galaxies.  The number of tiny galaxies we found is consistent with what we would expect, based on our understanding of the universe.  However, we found that the tiny galaxies are affected by their closeness to Magellanic Cloud-mass galaxies more than we expected.  The Magellanic Cloud-mass galaxies stopped many of the tiny galaxies from forming stars once the tiny galaxies got close.  Using simple theoretical models for how stars form in galaxies, we determined that the main physical reason that the tiny galaxies stop forming stars is likely different from the main reason that tiny galaxies near the Milky Way stop forming stars.  

 

This award supported the STEMcoding project to bring coding into high schools by spurring the creation of new YouTube videos and supporting code development for the STEMcoding website.  This award also supported leadership development for the Polaris near-peer mentoring program for OSU physics and astronomy students.  

 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Annika Peter

Images (1 of )
  • Fraction of synthetic versions of the Antlia and Antlia B galaxies that have the right atomic gas mass as a function of when the galaxies fell in toward NGC 3109, for a specific model of how small galaxies stop forming stars.
    Garling et al. 2024
    Creative Commons
    Annika Peter
    Successful synthetic Antlias
  • Average number of small galaxies near big galaxies, as a function of how faint the small galaxies are relative to the bright ones, and as a function of the big galaxy stellar mass and time.
    Roberts et al. 2021
    Creative Commons
    Annika Peter
    COSMOS satellites
  • A new tiny galaxy, MADCASH 2, discovered near NGC 4214
    Carlin et al. 2021
    Creative Commons
    Annika Peter
    MADCASH 2
  • Radial velocity of simulated small galaxies vs. distance to a synthetic NGC 2403 galaxy. The small galaxy DDO 44 is being spaghettified by NGC 2403. This plot helps us figure out how rare or common an event like that is.
    Carlin et al. 2019
    Creative Commons
    Annika Peter
    Infall times
por.por_txt_cntn:
Our Milky Way galaxy is surrounded by dozens of tiny galaxies, swirling around us. The number of these tiny galaxies tell us something about what our universe is made of and how it grew. The colors of these galaxies, and the ages of the stars in them, tell us how these smallest of galaxies grow, and how their growth is affected by their closeness to the Milky Way.





The goal of this study is to count tiny galaxies near galaxies smaller than the Milky Way (in particular, around galaxies similar to the Magellanic Clouds, which are visible in the southern sky), and determine if they behave the same way as tiny galaxies do around the Milky Way. We used telescopes in Chile, Hawaii, and space to find and measure these tiny galaxies. The number of tiny galaxies we found is consistent with what we would expect, based on our understanding of the universe. However, we found that the tiny galaxies are affected by their closeness to Magellanic Cloud-mass galaxies more than we expected. Using simple theoretical models for how stars form in galaxies, we determined that the main physical reason that the tiny galaxies stop forming stars is likely different from the main reason that tiny galaxies near the Milky Way stop forming stars.





This award supported the STEMcoding project to bring coding into high schools by spurring the creation of new YouTube videos and supporting code development for the STEMcoding website. This award also supported leadership development for the Polaris near-peer mentoring program for OSU physics and astronomy students.
